title: 111_s2768
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010" and authorizes appropriations. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 authorizes appropriations of $98,050,000 for fiscal year 2011 and 2012. The Board is authorized to impose and collect fees for activities and services provided. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2011 and 2012. Fees collected are credited to relevant accounts, available for associated costs, and remain available until expended. The Board maintains annual records of collections and can issue refunds for overpayments. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2011 and 2012, with fees collected credited to relevant accounts. Annual records of collections are maintained, and refunds can be issued for overpayments. Technical corrections are addressed in Section 3. Amendments include expanding the definition of incidents to include those significantly affecting transportation safety and granting the Board authority to subpoena witnesses and obtain evidence for accident investigations. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 expands the disclosure, availability, and use of information related to accident investigations and safety studies. Amendments include adding commercial or financial information to protected trade secrets, issuing safety reports, and recommendations. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 expands disclosure of trade secrets and financial information for accident investigations and safety studies. Amendments require annotating restricted information submitted to the Board for proper handling. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 allows the Board to withhold records related to ongoing investigations from public disclosure, except when necessary for transportation safety promotion. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 allows the Board to withhold specific factual material from ongoing investigations unless necessary for safety recommendations or dialogue with relevant entities. This subsection does not prevent the Board from using evidence from ongoing investigations for safety recommendations. Ongoing investigations are defined as the period from notification of an accident or incident until the issuance of a final report or closure of the investigation. This includes prescribing requirements for reporting accidents and incidents that may be investigated by the Board. Additionally, the Act amends the discovery and use of cockpit and surface vehicle recordings and transcripts. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 grants the Board the authority to withhold certain factual material from ongoing investigations, except when needed for safety recommendations or communication with relevant parties. This includes setting rules for reporting accidents and incidents under investigation. Additionally, the Act modifies the access and utilization of cockpit and surface vehicle recordings and transcripts. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 amends sections related to evaluation, audit, training of employees, accident investigation authority, and collections under specific provisions. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 includes amendments related to accidents and incidents, including those involving fatalities, property damage, environmental harm, international requests, and delegations. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 includes amendments related to accidents and incidents significantly affecting transportation safety, with detailed rules prescribed by the Board for investigations. Amendments include inserting "or incident" after "accident," adding "or relevant to" after "developed about," and specifying "Accident and Incident" in the heading for subsection (e) and in the text. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 allows the Board to delegate full authority to the Department of Transportation to investigate aviation accidents or incidents. The on-scene representative of the Secretary can enter accident sites and gather evidence with proper credentials and notice. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 delegates full authority to the Coast Guard for investigating maritime accidents. This includes allowing Coast Guard representatives to enter accident sites and gather evidence with proper credentials and notice. Additionally, section 1132 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to focus on civil aircraft and maritime accident investigations. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 delegates full authority to the Coast Guard for investigating maritime accidents, allowing representatives to gather evidence at accident sites. Section 1132 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to focus on civil aircraft and maritime accident investigations, including the Board's authority to download or seize recording devices and require specific information from manufacturers. The National Transportation Safety Board Reauthorization Act of 2010 grants the Coast Guard full authority to investigate maritime accidents, allowing them to download or seize recording devices and require specific information from manufacturers. Section 1132 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for accessing trade secrets or commercial information related to accident vehicles, vessels, or rolling stock. SEC. 5. Aviation penalties and family assistance are amended to ensure that families of passengers are notified before the destruction of unclaimed possessions in commercial aviation accidents. SEC. 6. A report on accident-related information release policy is required. Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the National Transportation Safety Board must submit a report to relevant committees detailing their policies for releasing accident-related information to various stakeholders. To amend title 49, United States Code, authorizing appropriations for the National Transportation Safety Board for fiscal years 2011 and 2012, and for other purposes.
